en_first_half: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the
en_second_half: Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)

They live in a picturesque and rugged country, and their history is full of romantic incidents. It is said that they have never been conquered, and that they have preserved their independence by the strength of their own arms. I am anxious to see these people and to learn something of their ways. The journey to their country is long and difficult, but I am determined to undertake it. The train takes me to Hermannstadt, the capital of the district, and from there I shall proceed on horseback. The scenery is magnificent, with its deep valleys and towering mountains, covered with dense forests. As I ride along, I can hear the distant howling of wolves, and see the flash of a lynx's eyes in the undergrowth. The people I meet are shy and suspicious, but they are also hospitable, and offer me food and shelter for the night. I am making slow progress, but I am learning much about the land and its people. The Szekelys are a proud and independent race, fiercely loyal to their traditions. Their villages are scattered across the rugged landscape, each with its own fortified church, a testament to the turbulent history of the region. The air is crisp and the nights are cold, but the beauty of the land makes the hardships worthwhile. As I continue my journey, I am filled with a sense of adventure and anticipation. The Szekelys are a people shrouded in mystery, and I am eager to uncover the secrets of their past and understand the essence of their culture.

Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body
en_second_half: of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.

En ese entonces, la atmósfera en Transilvania era de tensión y misterio, especialmente alrededor del castillo Drácula, ubicado en una colina remota y rodeado de montañas impensadas. La llegada de Jonathan Harker al castillo, destinado a ayudar al peculiar anfitrión en sus negocios, marcó el comienzo de una serie de eventos que desencadenarían una serie de eventos sobrenaturales y horripilantes. Harker, cautivado inicialmente por la belleza del lugar y la peculiaridad de su anfitrión, pronto descubriría la oscuridad que se escondía detrás de la cortesía excesiva de Drácula. La presencia de las tres mujeres, las "novias de Drácula", y la misteriosa ausencia de la luz del sol durante días completos aumentaban la sensación de terror y desconcierto. La historia se desplazaba entre la realidad y lo sobrenatural, con insinuaciones de vampirismo y maldad antigua. La figura de Van Helsing, un erudito en demonología, se convierte en el último esperanza para enfrentarse a esta amenaza antigua, guiando a los personajes principales en un desesperado intento de derrotar al poderoso vampiro. La narrativa de "Drácula" de Bram Stoker es un clásico del género de terror, lleno de simbolismo, suspense y reflexiones sobre la naturaleza del mal. La historia se desarrolla en un contexto histórico específico, con referencias a la Europa del siglo XIX, lo que añade una capa de realismo a la trama ficticia. La lucha entre la luz y la oscuridad, el conocimiento científico y la superstición, y la búsqueda de la redención frente al mal absoluto, son temas centrales que mantienen a la obra relevante hasta el día de hoy.
